posts.author: TychoVelius
posts.content:
I struggle with the CBC spreadsheet, so when I'm roughing out ideas I use scratch paper, in this case literally the back of an envelope.

Trying to make a rapier/dagger fencer. Qualifications are weaponmaster in both, Epic Dodge, and relatively soloable. Led me to go Fighter/Weaponmaster/Rogue, and looking at other builds I decided on a Rogue13/Fighter8/WM19 split. 

And good lord, is it hard to squeeze in all the feats for this. The need to go Ambi/TWF right off the bat sets me back, and now my little list is down to level 13 and I've got Weaponmaster levels online, but still haven't found room for Weapon Specialization in either weapon. Considering a R13/F14/WM13 split, just because of how feat-hungry the build is.

That and I second-guess myself constantly. Oh, well. Time to go to bed, and tomorrow find another envelope and spend a few hours on the wiki.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
To qualify for WM takes 6 feats, dual wield another 3. Add WS and you probably want blind fight, knockdown and improved critical as well. If 13 rogue indicates a dex build, you need weapon finesse. If not, you may want to qualify for dev crit.
I guess you see where this is going.
If you want to cram too much into a build, a typical beginners mistake, you often end up making it weaker.
A dual wielding weaponmaster is well within that limit of what can be a good build, and can be very powerful. But you start to feel the need for more fests, and it is tempting to weaken the build by taking more fighter and less weaponmaster.

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Hey man! Even though Ranger / Monk would probably save you many feats for dual-wielding / utility, you'd still be stuck with all the heavy WM requirements and ZERO bonus feats from Fighter or CoT to help you reach them.

I think the lesson here is that SOMETHING has to give. Either you drop WM or dual-wielding or dual-weapons. Why go through all that trouble just to have a slightly better weapon on the main hand than off-hand? If you want a Fighter / WM dual-wielder, why not go dual-dagger and Halfling? Higher AB and AC, no penalties involved, since dual-wielding daggers is doable, and there are some pretty sweet daggers on WoG too!

My thought was simply that delaying taking Weapon Master until post-level 20 might actually give a bit more leeway at earlier levels, rather than rushing for WM asap. It was only a thought, though.
@ Tycho

As long as you drop SOMETHING, it's fine. IMO, what would change the build the least would be just going with the same weapon in both hands. You're saving up a lot of feats that way, which will get you what you need.

@ Stag

You still only have so many feats, not counting bonus feats, here's the math:

1, 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18 - these are the GENERAL feats you get, which adds up to 7 (8 if you're Human)

Here's what he'd need to be able to get all he wants in this build:

Expertise, Dodge, Mobility, Spring Attack, Whirlwind Attack, Weapon Finesse, Weapon Focus (x2 if going for 2 Weapons), Two-weapon Fighting, Ambidexterity, Improved two-weapon fighting, Knockdown (on WoG, if you don't have KD, it's impossible to solo, Especially being new and unfamiliar with the server)

This adds up to 12 feats, which is 4 more than he possesses already, and they're just the bare minimum, there are a few VERY USEFUL feats that aren't there either: Weapon Specialization (x2 if you go for 2 weapons), Blind Fight and even Improved Critical (x2 for 2 weapons) and IKD.

I'm no mathematician, but even I know that'll be very hard to achieve without taking Pre-epic feats in epics, which, as Mick mentioned, weakens the build overall, because every pre-epic feat you take in epics is one less epic (better) feat you take. Furthermore, although it could technically be compensated by Fighter bonus feats, every Fighter level he takes beyond level 8 will weaken the build, because he'll be taking 1 more pre-epic feat by trading 6 WM for 6 FTR levels, but at the cost of 2 AB from Superior Weapon Focus in the final spread. That's a bad tradeoff.

@Tycho (conclusion)

As you see, Tycho, you're just trying the impossible. But, don't toss out your idea just yet. IMO you can maintain the main idea if you swap WM for CoT. Fighter / CoT / Rogue is a VERY feat-heavy build and you'll be rid of the heavy WM requirements, from which this concept won't be able to extract as much benefit due to level constraints. Then you'll have so many bonus feats it may actually be doable. Something like Fighter 14 / CoT 10 / Rogue 16 could work. Why don't you try building that?

And yeah, as Mick pointed out, Rogue alone will allow you to qualify for Epic Dodge.

Take it EZ!

EDIT @Stag - this is the answer to your question.

Actually, I did write a message to answer this, but I didn't hit Send LOL

Complementing Empyre's answer here, there are 2 paths to achieve that and both are bad:

1- you bring Rogue levels to pre-epic, delaying Fighter levels a bit. You lose 2 pre-epic BAB that way. You also only have 1 Rogue level left for skill dumps in epics.

2- you swap 6 Fighter for 6 WM, losing 2 epic feats and 2 AB from SWF for 3 pre-epic feats so you can have more fighter pre-epic. You end at Ftr 14 R 13 WM 13

As you see, both alternatives to delaying WM are a bad tradeoff.
